title: Change in kinetic energy from different forces

content.question:
Cart Mass <math alttext="in kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> 
Applied Force <math alttext="in newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>N</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> 
Time Force is Exerted <math alttext="in seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>s</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> 
Final Momentum <math alttext="in kilogram meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>â‹…</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> 
Final Kinetic Energy <math alttext="in joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>J</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> 

<math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></math> 

Two frictionless lab carts start from rest and are pushed along a level surface by a constant force. Students measure the magnitude and duration of the force on each cart, as shown in the partially completed data table above, and calculate final kinetic energy and momentum. Which cart has a greater kinetic energy at the end of the push?

choices.label: The <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>1 kg</mtext></mrow></math> cart
The <math alttext="2 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>2 kg</mtext></mrow></math> cart
Both carts have the same amount of kinetic energy.
The relationship cannot be determined without knowing the distance each cart moved as the force was being applied.

content.answer: The <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>1 kg</mtext></mrow></math> cart

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
